body:
It is pretty pointless to have a "private profile" if someone can just search for your username on Google with site:ruqqus.com and find all your posts / comments. In fact it is a bit problematic to give people a false sense of security by providing this feature but having it not really protect them.

Is there a way you can remove people's username from the comments section on the version of the website that is served to search engines? Or maybe just don't show the username at all when they have a private profile. There isn't really any reason we need to see usernames, right?
body_html:

body:
Huh. Brb. Changing my username to commonly used term. I wonder if @biden is taken.

Edit: It was a joke, but I was surprised @biden didn't appear to be taken, so I looked and the account has been banned "Reason: This account was created as part of a Ruqqus vote manipulation attempt and has now been suspended." I'm hoping that's old, but I want to say for the record I didn't actually make an alt. It does seem like your comments would be slightly harder to parse if you have some generic, common word or name as your username rather than a distinctive username.

post.body:
It is pretty pointless to have a "private profile" if someone can just search for your username on Google with site:ruqqus.com and find all your posts / comments. In fact it is a bit problematic to give people a false sense of security by providing this feature but having it not really protect them.

Is there a way you can remove people's username from the comments section on the version of the website that is served to search engines? Or maybe just don't show the username at all when they have a private profile. There isn't really any reason we need to see usernames, right?

body:
No; it depends on what the permalink is pointing to. Post permalinks (that show up with the post title and author as the title/description metadata) will get "please don't index me" if the post creator is in private mode.

Comment permalinks (that show up with "@[username] comments on [post title]" and the comment text as the title and description metadata) get the "please don't index me" if the comment author is in private mode.

The intention is to stop searches like the following from working on users with private mode enabled: https://www.google.com/search?q=%40lifeextensionforall+site%3Aruqqus.com&oq=%40lifeextensionforall+site%3Aruqqus.com
body_html:
No; it depends on what the permalink is pointing to. Post permalinks (that show up with the post title and author as the title/description metadata) will get "please don't index me" if the post creator is in private mode.

Comment permalinks (that show up with "@[username] comments on [post title]" and the comment text as the title and description metadata) get the "please don't index me" if the comment author is in private mode.

The intention is to stop searches like the following from working on users with private mode enabled: https://www.google.com/search?q=%40lifeextensionforall+site%3Aruqqus.com&oq=%40lifeextensionforall+site%3Aruqqus.com

body:
a .htaccess could probably do this too as a stop gap.  I don't think search engines remove such things when it recrawls.  not sure how long that is.


`RewriteEngine On`

`RewriteCond %{HTTP_REFERER} !^$`

`RewriteCond %{HTTP_REFERER} !^http://(www)?\ruqqus\.com`

`RewriteRule ^path/to/your-document\.html$ - [F]`


just need to install mod_rewrite (assuming apache)

parent.body:
No; it depends on what the permalink is pointing to. Post permalinks (that show up with the post title and author as the title/description metadata) will get "please don't index me" if the post creator is in private mode.

Comment permalinks (that show up with "@[username] comments on [post title]" and the comment text as the title and description metadata) get the "please don't index me" if the comment author is in private mode.

The intention is to stop searches like the following from working on users with private mode enabled: https://www.google.com/search?q=%40lifeextensionforall+site%3Aruqqus.com&oq=%40lifeextensionforall+site%3Aruqqus.com

post.body:
It is pretty pointless to have a "private profile" if someone can just search for your username on Google with site:ruqqus.com and find all your posts / comments. In fact it is a bit problematic to give people a false sense of security by providing this feature but having it not really protect them.

Is there a way you can remove people's username from the comments section on the version of the website that is served to search engines? Or maybe just don't show the username at all when they have a private profile. There isn't really any reason we need to see usernames, right?

post.title: Serious Problem with Private Profiles

body:
Am I missing something?

* If a post permalink (e.g. https://ruqqus.com/post/2ewm/serious-problem-with-private-profiles ) does not have no-index set, then all of the contents of the page will be indexed. 

* There is no way to stop Google indexing individual elements on the page - they either don't index the page at all, or they index the whole thing.

* The contents of the page does include the usernames of the people who commented.

So no matter what you do, short of blocking all indexing, it will always be possible to find a user's comments with a search like "site:ruqqus.com <username>".

Am I wrong?
body_html:
Am I missing something?

  • If a post permalink (e.g. https://ruqqus.com/post/2ewm/serious-problem-with-private-profiles ) does not have no-index set, then all of the contents of the page will be indexed.

  • There is no way to stop Google indexing individual elements on the page - they either don't index the page at all, or they index the whole thing.

  • The contents of the page does include the usernames of the people who commented.

So no matter what you do, short of blocking all indexing, it will always be possible to find a user's comments with a search like "site:ruqqus.com <username>".

Am I wrong?

parent.body:
No; it depends on what the permalink is pointing to. Post permalinks (that show up with the post title and author as the title/description metadata) will get "please don't index me" if the post creator is in private mode.

Comment permalinks (that show up with "@[username] comments on [post title]" and the comment text as the title and description metadata) get the "please don't index me" if the comment author is in private mode.

The intention is to stop searches like the following from working on users with private mode enabled: https://www.google.com/search?q=%40lifeextensionforall+site%3Aruqqus.com&oq=%40lifeextensionforall+site%3Aruqqus.com

parent.body:
a .htaccess could probably do this too as a stop gap.  I don't think search engines remove such things when it recrawls.  not sure how long that is.


`RewriteEngine On`

`RewriteCond %{HTTP_REFERER} !^$`

`RewriteCond %{HTTP_REFERER} !^http://(www)?\ruqqus\.com`

`RewriteRule ^path/to/your-document\.html$ - [F]`


just need to install mod_rewrite (assuming apache)

[edit]: wtf isn't code a markup lol  many edits for formatting and yes i copied and pasted. quicker than remembering how to do it off the top of my head

body:
Step #1: Private profiles should post a message about being private if user is not logged in. Currently bots like Googlebot and Bingbot do not signin to websites so they won't see any data posted to the page.

Step #2: All current private profiles can be exported to CSS and removed via Google Search Console for immediate removal (painful, manual, task).

Step #3: All private profiles should use a robots noindex, nofollow meta tag to ensure they are removed.

Edit, it looks like y'all have this handled correctly now. It takes Google time to crawl and recognize the "noindex" so expect your private profiles to hang around for a bit.
body_html:
Step #1: Private profiles should post a message about being private if user is not logged in. Currently bots like Googlebot and Bingbot do not signin to websites so they won't see any data posted to the page.

Step #2: All current private profiles can be exported to CSS and removed via Google Search Console for immediate removal (painful, manual, task).

Step #3: All private profiles should use a robots noindex, nofollow meta tag to ensure they are removed.

Edit, it looks like y'all have this handled correctly now. It takes Google time to crawl and recognize the "noindex" so expect your private profiles to hang around for a bit.

post.body:
It is pretty pointless to have a "private profile" if someone can just search for your username on Google with site:ruqqus.com and find all your posts / comments. In fact it is a bit problematic to give people a false sense of security by providing this feature but having it not really protect them.

Is there a way you can remove people's username from the comments section on the version of the website that is served to search engines? Or maybe just don't show the username at all when they have a private profile. There isn't really any reason we need to see usernames, right?
post.body_html:

Is there a way you can remove people's username from the comments section on the version of the website that is served to search engines? Or maybe just don't show the username at all when they have a private profile. There isn't really any reason we need to see usernames, right?
